title: Historic transactions seem to get lost when upgrading 1.9.9 => 1.10.1
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `Geth/v1.10.1-stable-c2d2f4ed/linux-amd64/go1.16`
OS & Version: Ubuntu 18.04
Chain: ropsten

#### Expected behaviour

After upgrading 1.9.9 to 1.10.1 historic transaction data should still be available.

#### Actual behaviour

After upgrading 1.9.9 to 1.10.1 historic transaction data is no longer available.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Upgrade to 1.10.1. Allow snapshot generation to complete.

#### Background & Logs

I have a couple testnet systems which I use to do testing with.  I upgraded one, ran my tests, and was surprised to find historic data missing.  I assumed this to be a fluke and nuked it and started a resync, I started with fast sync, then converted to full sync.  This too resulted in missing historic data.  I am now trying to do a full sync from the beginning to see if the historic data still disappears.  In the meantime, here is a log of a second system I upgraded, and was able to capture along the way.

```
Geth 1.10.1 started with:

geth/geth --ropsten --syncmode=full --rpcapi eth,web3,admin,personal,net --rpc

$ ./attach.sh

at block: 7015750 (Sun Dec 22 2019 18:01:26 GMT-0800 (PST))

To exit, press ctrl-d

$ ./attach.sh 
Welcome to the Geth JavaScript console!

24H later:

INFO [03-25|11:58:09.938] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1       txs=0        mgas=0.000    elapsed=5.492ms       mgasps=0.000    number=9908257 hash="9c03a9…b561ad" dirty=248.59MiB

$ ./attach.sh 
Welcome to the Geth JavaScript console!

instance: Geth/v1.10.1-stable-c2d2f4ed/linux-amd64/go1.16
coinbase: 0x0efa954df578e3589694467d2698837b57d80fad
at block: 9908260 (Thu Mar 25 2021 11:58:27 GMT-0700 (PDT))
 datadir: /home/eth/.ethereum/ropsten
 modules: admin:1.0 debug:1.0 eth:1.0 ethash:1.0 miner:1.0 net:1.0 personal:1.0 rpc:1.0 txpool:1.0 web3:1.0

To exit, press ctrl-d
> eth.syncing
false
> eth.getTransactionReceipt('0x17b7b887fcb5e02da1dabdb4b308d52786f9e634d0e43d7649a59421a11573cf');
null
> eth.getTransaction('0x17b7b887fcb5e02da1dabdb4b308d52786f9e634d0e43d7649a59421a11573cf');
null
```
If you just set back a higher txlookuplimit, the old txes will become indexed again.

Ahh!  I had read the pruning and optimizations sections, thinking maybe pruning had been introduced and didn't even think it'd be something related to database changes.  Makes perfect sense.

If all the block data is still intact and it's just the indexes missing I might suggest that a block scan option be introduced.  Eg, if I really need a previous transaction, I could step backward using a paginated scan with something like:

eth.getTransaction('0x123', 100000, 110000)
eth.getTransactionReceipt('0x123', 100000, 110000)

I'll add that flag to my startup scripts and come back and close this if the transaction history comes back.

Thanks!
Following up - the historic transactions came back. Thanks again!
